column1: Dodge City is the county seat of Ford County
column2: Kansas
column3: United States
column4: named after nearby Fort Dodge. The city is famous in American culture for its history as a wild frontier town of the Old West.  As of the 2010 census
column5: the city population was 27

column1: Fort Mann was the first settlement of nonindigenous people in the area that became Dodge City
column2: built by civilians in 1847 (the territory then being part of Mexico) to provide protection for travelers on the Santa Fe Trail. Fort Mann collapsed in 1848 after an Indian attack. In 1850
column3: the U.S. Army arrived to provide protection in the region and constructed Fort Atkinson on the old Fort Mann site. The army abandoned Fort Atkinson in 1853. Military forces on the Santa Fe Trail were re-established farther north and east at Fort Larned in 1859
column4: but the area remained vacant around what would become Dodge City until the end of the Civil War. In April 1865
column5: the Indian Wars in the West began heating up
column6: and the army constructed Fort Dodge to assist Fort Larned in providing protection on the Santa Fe Trail. Fort Dodge remained in operation until 1882.

column1: The town of Dodge City can trace its origins to 1871
column2: when rancher Henry J. Sitler built a sod house west of Fort Dodge to oversee his cattle operations in the region
column3: conveniently located near the Santa Fe Trail and Arkansas River
column4: and Sitler's house quickly became a stopping point for travelers. Others saw the commercial potential of the region with the Santa Fe Railroad rapidly approaching from the east. In 1872
column5: Dodge City was staked out on the 100th meridian and the legal western boundary of the Fort Dodge reservation. The town site was platted and  George M. Hoover established the first bar in a tent to serve thirsty soldiers from Fort Dodge. The railroad arrived in September to find a town ready and waiting for business. The early settlers in Dodge City traded in buffalo bones and hides and provided a civilian community for Fort Dodge. However
column6: with the arrival of the railroad
column7: Dodge City soon became involved in the cattle trade.

column1: The idea of driving Texas Longhorn cattle from Texas to railheads in Kansas originated in the late 1850s
column2: but was cut short by the Civil War. In 1866
column3: the first Texas cattle started arriving in Baxter Springs in southeastern Kansas by way of the Shawnee Trail.  However
column4: Texas Longhorn cattle carried a tick that spread Texas cattle fever
column5: among other breeds of cattle. Alarmed Kansas farmers persuaded the Kansas State Legislature to establish a quarantine line in central Kansas.  The quarantine prohibited Texas Longhorns from the heavily settled

column1: With the cattle trade forced west
column2: Texas Longhorns began moving north along the Chisholm Trail. In 1867
column3: the main cowtown was Abilene
column4: Kansas. Profits were high
column5: and other towns quickly joined in the cattle boom: Newton in 1871
column7: and Wichita in 1872. However
column9: the Kansas State Legislature responded to pressure from farmers settling in central Kansas and once again shifted the quarantine line westward
column10: which essentially eliminated Abilene and the other cowtowns from the cattle trade. With no place else to go
column11: Dodge City suddenly became the "queen of the cow towns".

column1: A new route known as the Great Western Cattle Trail or Western Trail branched off from the Chisholm Trail to lead cattle into Dodge City. Dodge City became a boomtown
column2: with thousands of cattle passing annually through its stockyards. The peak years of the cattle trade in Dodge City were from 1883 to 1884
column3: and during that time the town grew tremendously.  In 1880
column4: Dodge City got a new competitor for the cattle trade from the border town of Caldwell. For a few years
column5: the competition between the towns was fierce
column6: but enough cattle were available for both towns to prosper.

column2: Dodge City became famous
column3: and no town could match its reputation as a true frontier settlement of the Old West. Dodge City had more famous (and infamous) gunfighters working at one time or another than any other town in the West
column4: many of whom participated in the Dodge City War of 1883.

column1: It boasted also the usual array of saloons
column2: gambling halls
column3: and brothels
column4: including the famous Long Branch Saloon and China Doll brothel. For a time in 1884
column5: Dodge City had even a bullfighting ring where Mexican bullfighters would put on a show with specially chosen Longhorn bulls.

column1: As more agricultural settlers moved into western Kansas
column2: pressure increased on the Kansas State Legislature to do something about splenic fever
column3: known today as anthrax. Consequently
column5: the quarantine line was extended across the state and the Western Trail was all but shut down. By 1886
column7: saloon keepers
column9: and brothel owners moved west to greener pastures
column10: and Dodge City became a sleepy little town much like other communities in western Kansas.

column2: −100.018212) at an elevation of 2
column3: 493 ft (760 m). It lies on the Arkansas River in the High Plains region of the Great Plains. The city sits above one of the world's largest underground water systems
column4: the Ogallala Aquifer
column5: and is 25 miles (40 km) from the eastern edge of the Hugoton Natural Gas Area. Located at the intersection of U. S. Routes 50
column7: Dodge City is 151 mi (243 km) west of Wichita
column9: and 301 mi (484 km) southeast of Denver.According to the United States Census Bureau
column10: the city has a total area of 14.55 square miles (37.68 km2)
column11: of which 14.44 square miles (37.40 km2) is land and 0.11 square miles (0.28 km2) is water.

column1: Dodge City lies at the intersection of North America's semi-arid (Köppen BSk) and humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) zones
column2: with hot summers
column3: highly variable winters
column4: both warm and very cold periods
column5: and low to moderate humidity and precipitation throughout the year; it is part of USDA Hardiness zone 6b. Areas to the west are drier and more strongly semi-arid. Severe weather
column7: is common in the area
column8: especially in the spring months. Dodge City is often cited as the windiest city in the United States with an average speed of 13.9 mph (22.4 km/h)
column9: which results in occasional blizzards in the winter
column10: even when snowfall does not accumulate much. On average
column13: and June is the wettest month.The normal annual mean temperature in Dodge City is 55.4 °F (13.0 °C)
column14: while the normal monthly daily average temperature ranges from 32.2 °F (0.1 °C) in January to 79.6 °F (26.4 °C) in July. The high temperature reaches or exceeds 90 °F (32 °C) an average of 67 days a year and reaches or exceeds 100 °F (38 °C) an average of 13 days a year; the last year that failed to reach 100 °F was 1958. The minimum temperature falls to or below 0 °F (−18 °C) an average of 3.0 days a year. The highest officially recorded temperature was 111 °F (44 °C) on June 27
column16: while the lowest temperature officially recorded was −26 °F (−32 °C) on February 12
column17: 1899. The record cold daily maximum is −13 °F (−25 °C) on January 13
column20: the record warm daily minimum is 81 °F (27 °C) last set July 12
column21: 1978.Dodge City receives an annual average of 21.6 inches (550 mm) in precipitation
column22: with the largest share being received from May through August; annual precipitation has historically ranged from 9.97 in (253 mm) in 1956 to 34.29 in (871 mm) in 1944. There are
column24: 77 days of measurable precipitation each year. Snowfall averages 21.1 inches (54 cm) per season
column25: although snowfall has historically ranged from 0.2 in (0.51 cm) in 1903–04 to 61.3 in (156 cm) in 1992–93. Measurable snowfall occurs an average of 14 days a year with at least an inch of snow being received on six of those days. Snow depth of at least an inch occurs an average of 19 days a year. The average window for overnight freezes is October 17 through April 21
column26: allowing a growing season of 178 days.

column1: Meat packing is the primary industry in Dodge City. Cargill Meat Solutions and National Beef both operate large facilities in the city. The city also hosts farm implement manufacturing and serves as a supply center for area agriculture. Livestock-raising is a major activity while wheat and sorghum are the area's main crops. In addition
column2: a local tourism industry
column3: including a casino resort
column4: has developed to capitalize on Dodge City's history as an Old West cowtown. The service sector accounts for much of the rest of the local economy.As of 2010
column5: 70.9% of the population over the age of 16 was in the labor force. 0.3% was in the armed forces
column6: and 70.5% was in the civilian labor force with 66.9% being employed and 3.6% unemployed. The composition
column7: by occupation
column8: of the employed civilian labor force was:  23.3% in management
column11: and arts; 16.4% in sales and office occupations; 10.9% in service occupations; 15.2% in natural resources
column15: and material moving. The three industries employing the largest percentages of the working civilian labor force were:  manufacturing (33.0%); educational services
column17: and social assistance (18.1%); and retail trade (9.4%).The cost of living in Dodge City is relatively low; compared to a U.S. average of 100
column18: the cost of living index for the city is 79.3. As of 2010
column19: the median home value in the city was $83

column1: Dodge City has a commission-manager form of government. The city commission consists of five members who serve either two-year or four-year terms
column2: depending on the number of votes they receive. Every year
column3: the commission selects one commissioner to serve as mayor and another to serve as vice-mayor. The commission meets on the first and third Mondays of each month. Appointed by the commission
column4: the city manager leads the city administration
column5: executes the commission's policies
column6: and develops operational programs to meet the city's needs.As the county seat
column7: Dodge City is the administrative center of Ford County. The county courthouse is located downtown
column8: and all departments of the county government base their operations in the city.Dodge City lies within Kansas's 1st U.S. Congressional District. For the purposes of representation in the Kansas Legislature
column9: the city is located in the 38th district of the Kansas Senate and the 115th and 119th districts of the Kansas House of Representatives.Dodge City was criticized by Johnny Dunlap
column11: for only having one polling place for 13
column13: it was moved outside the city limits one mile from the nearest bus stop. While the county provided transportation
column14: voters had to arrange for it in advance. A lawsuit over the issue was dismissed after Debbie Cox
column16: agreed to open two polling places in the next election.

column1: The Western Plains Medical Complex is the sole hospital in Dodge City. A 100-bed hospital accredited by the Joint Commission
column2: it serves as a referral center for southwestern Kansas.

column16: starts in late November and lasts until Christmas. It begins with a formal Christmas tree lighting downtown

column1: Located in and around the city are a number of historical sites
column2: museums
column3: and landmarks dedicated to Dodge City's Old West heritage.  The Boot Hill Museum
column4: located downtown
column5: contains thousands of artifacts and a variety of exhibits portraying the culture of the city's early years. The museum's larger exhibits include:  Front Street
column6: a partial reconstruction of downtown Dodge City as it existed in 1876; the Long Branch Saloon and the Long Branch Variety Show; the Saratoga Saloon; the Hardesty House
column7: a period-typical home built in 1879; the city's original Boot Hill Cemetery; and the Kansas Cowboy Hall of Fame. The Santa Fe Trail Remains
column8: located 9 miles (14 km) west of the city
column9: are preserved wagon tracks from a section of the Santa Fe Trail. The Ford County Historical Society maintains the Mueller-Schmidt House
column10: called the "Home of Stone." Built from area limestone in 1881
column11: it is the oldest building in the city still standing at its original site. Other historical landmarks include:  El Capitan
column12: a life-sized bronze sculpture of a Texas Longhorn steer built to commemorate the cattle drives that once ended in the city; a bronze statue of famous Dodge City lawman Wyatt Earp; and the Santa Fe Depot
column13: the largest extant train depot in Kansas.

column2: the city promotes its downtown business district as historic Old Dodge City complete with Western-themed tourist attractions
column3: shops
column4: and restaurants. Visitors can tour the district by trolley or by taking the Dodge City Trail of Fame walking tour. The state of Kansas operates the similarly themed Boot Hill Casino & Resort on the west side of the city – when it opened for business in December 2009
column5: Boot Hill became the first state-owned casino in the United States.Dodge City Civic Center and United Wireless Arena are the city's two main indoor event venues. The Civic Center
column7: is a 2
column8: 800-seat multipurpose facility that has hosted a variety of events

column15: the Kansas Teachers' Hall of Fame hosts exhibits on education in Kansas and claims to be the first of its kind in the United States.

column1: There are 33 Christian churches in and around Dodge City. The Roman Catholic Diocese of Dodge City is based in the city. Established in 1951
column2: it comprises 28 Kansas counties
column3: roughly the southwestern quarter of the state. The city is home to the diocese's current cathedral as well as its former cathedral
column4: the Cathedral of Our Lady of Guadalupe and Sacred Heart Cathedral
column5: respectively. Also headquartered in the city is the Dodge City District of the United Methodist Church which consists of 22 counties in southwestern Kansas.

column1: Dodge City Community College's athletic teams

column4: Dodge City also hosts amateur baseball and professional motorsports. The Dodge City Athletics
column5: nicknamed the "A's"

column7: located on the former St. Mary of the Plains College campus

column9: located immediately south of the city

column2: the violent episodes of early Dodge City history
column3: particularly the exploits of Wyatt Earp
column4: attracted national media attention. National news coverage of the 1883 Dodge City War civil strife fueled public perceptions of frontier turmoil and established Dodge City as the "Sodom of the West" in the public consciousness. Gunfighters and lawmen such as Earp and his brothers and partners became celebrities
column5: and sensationalized versions of their activities entered period popular culture as the subject of dime novels. Over time
column6: the level and scale of the violence in early Dodge City were significantly embellished
column7: becoming the stuff of legend. This trend continued into the 20th century
column8: particularly after the 1931 publication of Stuart N. Lake's book Wyatt Earp: Frontier Marshal. Regarded in American folklore as the quintessential rough and rowdy Old West frontier town
column9: Dodge City served as the setting for numerous works of Western-themed media
column10: including later popular films and television series.Dodge City was the setting of the long-running radio and television series Gunsmoke. The series followed the adventures of fictional U.S. Marshal Matt Dillon portrayed first by William Conrad and then by James Arness
column13: gamblers and other criminals while enforcing the law in the frontier town. The radio series starring William Conrad lasted from 1952 to 1961 while the television series ran from 1955 to 1975
column14: on the CBS television network (Columbia Broadcasting System)
column15: the longest-running prime-time TV drama in American history. The show proved to be culturally influential and promoted the legend of Dodge City's Old West era. It also served as the source of the idiom "get [the hell] out of Dodge" which means to leave a dangerous area quickly. In honor of the series
column16: the city government changed the name of Walnut Street
column19: in 1959.The city has also been a setting for a number of films and television series dramatizing the career of Wyatt Earp. These include several seasons of the  series The Life and Legend of Wyatt Earp starring Hugh O'Brian on the ABC television network from 1955 to 1961
column21: with James Stewart Masterson of Kansas (1954)
column25: James Stewart and Edward G. Robinson and directed by John Ford and Wyatt Earp (1994) with Kevin Costner and Gene Hackman.  In the 1939 film Dodge City the fictional lawman Wade Hatton
column27: was modeled on Earp.In the television series Smallville
column28: Metropolis is said to be southwest of Dodge City with Smallville
column29: "Superman" / Clark Kent's childhood and adolescent residence
column30: located 200 miles (320 km) west of Wichita.More recently
column31: Dodge City served as a setting for the 2005 multi-platform video game Gun.
